cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ghostly apparitions are presented as a type of supernatural or paranormal phenomenon within urban legends.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeContext: elements of urban legend stories

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The allure of the unknown is paired with the experience of a good scare as joint emotional draws of urban legends.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Urban Legend Emotional Themes and Responses

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Effect: both contribute to enduring popularity of urban legends

remarks: Relation models their joint role in audience attraction; semantics are associative rather than strictly causal.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Dark pasts of haunted houses are linked to the sense of lurking dangers.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StoryRole: threat backstory for haunted houses

remarks: Semantics somewhat indirect; relation mainly captures that dark pasts contribute to perceived danger.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Cursed objects in stories are thematically linked to lurking dangers.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeFunction: example of a dangerous or ominous object

remarks: Could also be modeled as cursed objects causing danger; text only implies this via the warning context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is an instance or specific type within the broader category represented by the object concept.
args.justification: The relation describes ghostly apparitions as a type of paranormal phenomenon, which is a clear category-membership / instance-of relation between a specific phenomenon and a broader concept.
The predicate links a specific phenomenon (ghostly apparitions) to a broader conceptual category (paranormal), fitting a category/ontology membership family of relations.
Category membership / instance-of semantics express an identity-like relationship between an instance and its type-level category.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are linked through narrative, emotional, or conceptual association within a thematic or story context, without asserting direct causality.
args.justification: All three relations describe non-causal, narrative or emotional linkages: (1) the unknown and a good scare as joint emotional draws; (2) dark pasts and dangers; (3) cursed objects and dangers. These are not strict causal mechanisms but thematic/emotional associations in stories, so a shared canonical predicate focusing on thematic association is appropriate.
args.remark: Use for narrative/emotional co-appearance or linkage where text does not clearly assert direct causality.

args.justification: Each relation connects elements that co-function within urban legends as joint themes (emotional draws, backstories, perceived dangers) rather than material interactions, fitting a shared class for narrative/thematic associations.
All three relations express non-causal, co-thematic linkage between concepts in stories; this is best captured under a broad ASSOCIATION group.
